message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has severe cerebral edema and diffuse axonal injury, suggesting the most likely type of herniation found at autopsy is central herniation. Uncal herniation is usually caused by a mass lesion on one side of the brain, while subfalcine herniation is caused by a midline mass effect. Downward cerebellar herniation is also known as tonsillar herniation, which is caused by increased pressure in the posterior fossa. None of these options match the patient’s symptoms as well as central herniation does.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has severe cerebral edema and multiple hemorrhages in the brainstem, which together suggest central herniation. Uncal herniation is characterized by compression of the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve, leading to pupillary dilation and eye movement abnormalities, which are not seen in this case. Subfalcine herniation is when the cingulate gyrus is pushed under the falx cerebri, but this would not cause the findings seen in this case. Downward cerebellar herniation involves the cerebellar tonsils moving downward through the foramen magnum, which is not seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has diffuse axonal injury and severe cerebral edema, which can cause central herniation. It is important to note that the other types of herniation (uncal, subfalcine, and downward cerebellar) can also occur in cases of severe traumatic brain injury, but the description of the patient's injury and imaging findings suggest a central herniation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation, including severe cerebral edema and multiple hemorrhages in the brainstem, suggests central herniation. Uncal herniation is usually a result of temporal lobe herniating over tentorium cerebelli, which is not indicative of the patient’s injury. Subfalcine herniation involves cingulate gyrus herniating under the falx cerebri, and downward cerebellar herniation involves cerebellar tonsils herniating through the foramen magnum, both of which are also not indicated by the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has severe cerebral edema, which can cause increased intracranial pressure and central herniation, where the brain is pushed downwards through the foramen magnum. Uncal herniation usually results from a mass effect in the temporal lobe, subfalcine herniation occurs when the brain shifts under the falx cerebri, and downward cerebellar herniation results from compression of the cerebellar tonsils. None of these would be the most likely type of herniation in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the MRI findings suggest severe cerebral edema, which can cause central herniation, where the brainstem passes through the tentorial notch. Uncal herniation would display ipsilateral pupillary dilation and hemiparesis, but the patient’s pupils are dilated and fixed. Subfalcine herniation would result in midline shift, but the MRI shows multiple frontal and occipital lobe contusions. Downward cerebellar herniation would lead to compression of the cerebellar tonsils, but the patient’s brainstem is affected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has severe cerebral edema, which can cause intracranial pressure to increase and lead to central herniation, where the brainstem herniates downward through the foramen magnum. Uncal herniation is caused by the displacement of the uncus and is usually seen with a unilateral supratentorial mass. Subfalcine herniation is caused by the cerebral hemisphere to herniate under the falx cerebri, which separates the two hemispheres. Downward cerebellar herniation is caused by the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest increased intracranial pressure, which can lead to central herniation. Uncal herniation is characterized by the medial temporal lobe moving over the tentorium cerebelli, subfalcine herniation is characterized by the cingulate gyrus moving under the falx cerebri, and downward cerebellar herniation is characterized by the cerebellar tonsils moving through the foramen magnum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s severe cerebral edema and multiple frontal and occipital lobe contusions and hemorrhages suggest that central herniation is the most likely type of herniation to be found at autopsy. Uncal herniation is associated with compression of the cerebral peduncle, subfalcine herniation is associated with herniation of one cerebral hemisphere under the falx cerebri, and downward cerebellar herniation is associated with compression of the brainstem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presented with severe cerebral edema, multiple contusions, and hemorrhages. This suggests that the most likely type of herniation found at autopsy would be a central herniation, where the brainstem is pushed downwards due to increased intracranial pressure. Uncal herniation is typically caused by a lesion in the temporal lobe and presents with ipsilateral dilated and fixed pupils. Subfalcine herniation is caused by displacement of the cingulate gyrus and presents with contralateral weakness. Downward cerebellar herniation is caused by a lesion in the posterior fossa and presents with respiratory depression and bradycardia.
